item.title: Fox add a quote by Alice Hoffman
item.description: "Jill told me that when you're really in love, you know right away. I'm not exactly sure how this happens. Is it like a flash of lightning? Like an angel tapping you on the shoulder? Or is it similar to choosing a puppy? You think you're picking the cutest one, but really you wind up going home with the one who keeps insisting on climbing into your lap." -- Alice Hoffman

item.title: Fox add a quote by Alice Hoffman
item.description: "Books may well be the only true magic." -- Alice Hoffman

item.title: Fox add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "The person, be it gentleman or lady, who has not pleasure in a good novel, must be intolerably stupid." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Fox add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "I do not want people to be very agreeable, as it saves me the trouble of liking them a great deal." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Fox add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "I declare after all there is no enjoyment like reading! How much sooner one tires of any thing than of a book! -- When I have a house of my own, I shall be miserable if I have not an excellent library." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Fox add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession of a good fortune, must be in want of a wife." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Fox add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "A lady's imagination is very rapid; it jumps from admiration to love, from love to matrimony in a moment." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Fox add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "There is nothing I would not do for those who are really my friends. I have no notion of loving people by halves, it is not my nature." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Fox add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "Ah! There is nothing like staying at home, for real comfort." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Fox add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "It is only a novel... or, in short, only some work in which the greatest powers of the mind are displayed, in which the most thorough knowledge of human nature, the happiest delineation of its varieties, the liveliest effusions of wit and humour, are conveyed to the world in the best-chosen language" -- Jane Austen

item.title: Fox add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "Angry people are not always wise." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Fox add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "It is not everyone,' said Elinor, 'who has your passion for dead leaves." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Fox add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "Seldom, very seldom, does complete truth belong to any human disclosure; seldom can it happen that something is not a little disguised or a little mistaken." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Fox add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "Nothing ever fatigues me, but doing what I do not like." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Fox add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "Life seems but a quick succession of busy nothings." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Fox add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "Silly things do cease to be silly if they are done by sensible people in an impudent way." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Fox add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "You must learn some of my philosophy. Think only of the past as its remembrance gives you pleasure." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Fox add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "Vanity and pride are different things, though the words are often used synonymously. A person may be proud without being vain. Pride relates more to our opinion of ourselves, vanity to what we would have others think of us." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Fox add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "Run mad as often as you choose, but do not faint!" -- Jane Austen

item.title: Fox add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "Better be without sense than misapply it as you do. " -- Jane Austen

item.title: Fox add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "I must learn to be content with being happier than I deserve." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Fox add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "I may have lost my heart, but not my self-control. " -- Jane Austen

item.title: Fox add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "One half of the world cannot understand the pleasures of the other." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Fox add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "I cannot speak well enough to be unintelligible." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Fox add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "There are people, who the more you do for them, the less they will do for themselves." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Fox add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "[I]t is well to have as many holds upon happiness as possible." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Fox add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "My idea of good company...is the company of clever, well-informed people, who have a great deal of conversation; that is what I call good company.' 'You are mistaken,' said he gently, 'that is not good company, that is the best." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Fox add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "We have all a better guide in ourselves, if we would attend to it, than any other person can be." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Fox add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "How quick come the reasons for approving what we like." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Fox add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "I . . . am always half afraid of finding a clever novel too clever--& of finding my own story & my own people all forestalled." -- Jane Austen
